unnormalised: **Manufacturing & Supply Chain: Quality Control Concerns Rise in Auto Ancillary Sector**
normalised: **Manufacturing and Supply Chain: Quality Control Concerns Rise in Auto Ancillary Sector**

unnormalised: Mumbai, October 26th – Concerns are mounting over quality control lapses within the auto ancillary sector, particularly amongst smaller manufacturers supplying to larger OEMs like Tata Motors and Mahindra. A recent audit revealed inconsistencies in raw material sourcing and adherence to standardized testing protocols.
normalised: Mumbai, October twenty sixth – Concerns are mounting over quality control lapses within the auto ancillary sector, particularly amongst smaller manufacturers supplying to larger O E M S like Tata Motors and Mahindra. A recent audit revealed inconsistencies in raw material sourcing and adherence to standardized testing protocols.

unnormalised: The issue came to light following increased customer complaints regarding component failures in recently launched vehicle models. "Maintaining robust quality control is paramount, especially when dealing with intricate parts," stated Dr. Sharma, Head of Engineering at IIT Kanpur, referencing the importance of precision in automotive manufacturing, akin to the meticulousness portrayed in classic films like "Rocket Singh: Salesman of the Year," where quality and integrity are key.

unnormalised: The Automotive Component Manufacturers Association of India (ACMA) is reportedly working with the Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS) to reinforce training programs and implement stricter auditing procedures. The current focus is on ensuring compliance with ISO 9001 standards. Several smaller units in industrial hubs like Pune and Chennai face potential penalties if deficiencies are not addressed swiftly. Failure rates have reportedly risen by 7%, costing the industry an estimated Rs. 50 crore in warranty claims. Stricter quality checks at the supplier end are expected to mitigate future risks. A new certification program costing approximately Rs. 25,000 per unit is being considered to improve transparency.
